utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: Visualizing? All right. You’re up, tiger. You feel all right? You look a little pale.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: I’m fine.

utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: Does your neck still hurt?

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: It’ll be fine.

utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: You know, maybe you should do the two and a half instead.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: I’m gonna do the three.

utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: Well, it’s better to nail the two and a half than –

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: I’m gonna nail the three.

utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: All right. Well, let’s show these senior citizens what a well-coached twelve-year-old can do, huh?

utterance.speaker: Announcer
utterance.content: The next diver: two-time National Junior Champion Mary Carroll.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: Damn it, you can do this, come on. Just… see it, see it. Big jump, let it count. Rip it.

utterance.speaker: A Coach
utterance.content: Call 911. We need an ambulance!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I saw the light on.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s daytime.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, it’s a figure of speech. Always so literal.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Got a new cane.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. Guy in the store said it was slimming. Vertical stripe…

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why are you here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Vogler is dead.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What? What happened?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Again with the literal translation. Vogler the idea, Mr. Destructo, Mr. Moneybags, bow down before me; he is gone from the hospital, so things can go back to the way they were.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The way they were was kind of weird.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Weird works for me.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What are you saying? Literally?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I want you to come back.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Please unclench. You’re not on the clock, and when you do that, I clench, and then it’s the whole thing…

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Could you look at your pager?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s no big deal, some sort of epidemic. Not my area.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You should go, it’s important.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What I’m doing now is important.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why do you want me back?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because you’re a good doctor.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That’s it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s not enough?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Not for me. Go deal with your plague.

utterance.speaker: Overhead speaker voice
utterance.content: You are in a quarantined area. Please remain calm and stay in line. A doctor will see you shortly. When you see a doctor, you will receive a blue or yellow form. Patients with blue forms must immediately enter the parking lot…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Dr. House! We need you here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry, lot of sick people. I might catch something.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: A judge at the campus pool center collapsed, LP revealed a virulent form of bacterial meningitis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Great, got it diagnosed, you don’t need me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: 2500 people at the pool center were exposed. They’re being bused to all the neighboring hospitals.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s a problem of resources, not diagnostics. No, I’d be completely lost, get in everyone’s way.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Joe! Dr. House doesn’t have a blue slip. No one leaves the quarantine area without a blue slip. You are a doctor at this hospital: act like one. And take these.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 102. You win a trip to the second floor. Next!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: All right, no fever, no rash, you’re fine. Take these two pills, and show this blue slip to Security on your way out. Next!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Take these, go home, talk to your daughter.

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your pants, your blouse, your scarf are all freshly dry cleaned. Everything except your jacket, it’s got a smudge on it. Probably two days old. Which means you didn’t know the jacket had been worn. So either your husband is a crossdresser or your daughter has been borrowing your clothes without telling you. Probably wants to look older to get into bars.

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: I don’t have a daughter.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Next!

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: So I have it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yellow form to the second form, you’re gonna be fine.

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: I’m gonna die!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s treatable as long as you go to the second floor. Next.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yow.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: Fever. Does that mean I have it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have a rash? Come on.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: It’s from my new bathing suit, I’ve had it a week.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. Does your neck hurt? If it does, you get the trifecta.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: It’s nothing. I pulled it trying to do a three-and-a-half tuck.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where are your parents?

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: We live in Chicago. I’m here with my coach. I wanted to see what you were writing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Go like this. Now like this.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Take these pills. A blue slip will get you out of here. Next!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re coming with me.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You’re going to need a CT scan. Second floor, take the elevators, follow the parade. Next!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Maybe something systemic.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or maybe it’s meningitis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s had the rash a week. If it was this meningitis, she’d be dead by now.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You guys figure we’re done down there? The 800 people milling around are just waiting for the bathroom?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 12-year-old female. Fever, rash, neck pains. Not meningitis.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s the definition of meningitis!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure, pus in the spinal canal makes it hurt to move your head up and down, but her head only hurts moving side to side.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh, side to side.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Doesn’t fit.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The three of you, lobby, now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Those little pills you’re passing out so efficiently aren’t going to do Miss Louganis squat.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You just don’t want to deal with the epidemic.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s right. I’m subjecting a 12-year-old to a battery of dangerous and evasive tests to avoid being bored. Okay, maybe I would do that, but I’m not. If it turns out she does have meningitis, you’re right, you win, but if we go back downstairs and she dies… your face will be so red.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You have one hour.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get a lumbar puncture. Some brain infections can be pretty clever at hide-and-seek.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’ll get on her bloodwork.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No you won’t. You, sir, will research all the causes in the universe of neck pain.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The list is, like, two miles long!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Start with the letter A. And put her on rifampin.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Rifampin is for meningitis. You just said –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: In case I’m wrong. It has happened.

utterance.speaker: Doctor 1
utterance.content: Brenda, I need a CBC count 7 and 2046.

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: Hold on.

utterance.speaker: Doctor 2
utterance.content: Hey, hey, there’s a line here!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That’s why I said ‘excuse me.’ Brenda, I need a bed, and…

utterance.speaker: Doctor 3
utterance.content: We all need stuff.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Push me again. Brenda, I need a bed and a nurse for a lumbar puncture.

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: No beds, no nurses for at least 4 hours.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’ve only got one.

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: Your patient only has an hour to live unless she gets a lumbar puncture?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Cuddy only gave us an hour to work on the patient.

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: Back of the line.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This novocaine will numb you for the lumbar puncture. Sorry this has to be so public, Mary.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: Normally I’m in a bathing suit with 5000 people staring at my butt. I can block this out.

utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: These kids are all very mature. Travel around the country from event to event.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Okay, I need you to hold your knees and tuck your head.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: Like a dive?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Exactly. Good, great. Don’t forget to breathe.

utterance.speaker: Person
utterance.content: Sorry!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Geez! Coach, help me out here, play a little defense before I poke the wrong thing? Okay, here we go.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: Ow, I feel, ow, I feel it, ow!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Try to relax, Mary, try to relax.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What letter are you up to?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: A.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Torture combing through all that stuff, ain’t it? Real dull. Awful.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s no problem.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, thank goodness. A lot of people would resent having to do this.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Where’s the 12-year-old girl that was here?

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Needed the gurney.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She just had a lumbar puncture, she’s not supposed to be moved!

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Sorry, we needed the gurney.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You okay? How’s your head feeling?

utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: She’s got a headache, and she’s dizzy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She shouldn’t have been moved after the procedure, I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: I’m fine, what did the test show?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No meningitis, no other infections.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: But you’re not carrying a blue form. I have something else, don’t I?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Something’s causing your symptoms. We’re going to keep you overnight. I know it’s a little crazy here, but hopefully things will settle down and we’ll get you a room.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: I’m sorry. I’m not usually all emotional like this.

utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: You’re doing great. Your folks will land in a few hours.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: I just… I haven’t slept, I’m so tired. Oh my God, my eye’s bleeding. What is it, what’s happening?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Oh, don’t worry. The antibiotic we gave you in case you had meningitis can turn your tears reddish. That’s not blood. But that… that’s blood.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: That’s going into my stomach?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The vials showed blood in your GI tract. We need to find out where it’s coming from. You won’t feel it. I’m going to numb the back of your throat and Dr. Foreman is going to give you a sedative. Open. Swallow. Now lay on your side for me. And here we go. Yell “fire,” or something.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: People, this area is highly contagious. Please step back. Highly contagious.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: All right. Try to relax, Mary, this shouldn’t take too long.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Don’t see any tears or lesions.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: All right, I’m in her stomach. There’s no bleeding.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There was more than a tablespoon of blood in her stomach, so it’s got to be there. Maybe her small intestine.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: 30 feet of digestive tract, it could be anywhere in there. We’re not going to see it with this.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Believe it or not, this is a camera. You swallow it, and it goes all the way through your system. The antennae pick up the signal from the pill. We’re going to look at the video of your intestines, see where the blood is coming from, and fix it. Water? Down the hatch.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Think I’ve seen this movie. The ending’s kind of dark. Want one? How come you did the endoscopy?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He asked for help!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Her blood pressure was high, I was worried –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Foreman is not your boss. When I tell you to do something – whoa. Hold it there. Back it up a couple of frames. Oh, yeah! That’s your money shot.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don’t see anything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Really? Ginormous thing on the right side of her intestine doesn’t even intrigue you?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Does ginormous mean really big or really, really big, ‘cause I don’t see anything.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There? A Dieulafoy?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Oh. Well, we can burn off the swollen blood vessel, but it still doesn’t account for her other symptoms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, but it does tell us something. Though I have no idea what.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be a precursor to intestinal intussusception.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Precursor isn’t causing all of her other symptoms. What else?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You, in the lobby, now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I hurt my leg. I have a note.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You had your hour. Three, actually.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dr. Chase, I told you to tell us when our time was up. She has intestinal bleeding.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She’ll wait. Two more buses just arrived. We need you downstairs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, you need more nurses. But you cut back on the nursing staff so you have doctors doing what the nurses should be doing.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That’s true. I wonder if that has anything to do you with you costing us $100 million.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Go, be free.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s not the intussusception, what about stomach cancer?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Does she have any abdominal pain?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Then it’s not stomach cancer. Have you ruled out sepsis?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The LP and blood smear showed no signs of infection. Here. Take these two pills and you can go.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, the lab’s working at double their capacity, maybe someone screwed up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No fever, no neck pain. Take the elevator to the third floor.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Whoa, whoa, whoa, wrong form. No fever, no neck pain, she’s fine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Smell her hair, no chlorine. Which means she wasn’t at the pool. Which means she’s come to a quarantined area because she’s a idiot or she’s insane. No one is that stupid. East wing, psych ward, bye-bye.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Neck pain could be a symptom for bone cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You up to Bs? Well done!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It would account for all her meningial symptoms. Rash, fever… You’re fine. Take these two pills…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get a sample of her bone marrow.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: From here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Break time.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Need more than 15 minutes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Use Chase’s break, too. Go.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You should just fire Chase.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What, and miss out on all this fun?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So you’re going to torture him for a while and then fire him? That’s cold.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don’t think he has it coming?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hey, I said fire him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s cold. All he did was save his job.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What? He completely screwed you over!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right rudder. Bank, bank, bank!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Good coffee? The rest of this hospital is busting it’s tail, and… What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Trying to think of anything except the produce department at Whole Foods.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I am… working, it got hot, stop acting like a 13-year-old!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry, you just don’t usually see breasts like that on Deans of Medicine.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh, women can’t be heads of hospitals? Or just ugly ones?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, they can be babes. You just don’t usually see their funbags.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Your 3 o’clock interview for Dr. Cameron’s position is in your office.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ah, not interviewing today. I don’t know if you’ve heard, but there’s this big time epidemic. Many sick people puking in the hallways, it’s crazy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’ll send the interview home, we can reschedule.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, you won’t. You will interview this person, and if he can put two sentences together you will send him to the lobby where he will do his job. Unlike the two of you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Come on, you know I can’t do a bone marrow aspiration in the hallway.

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: And I can’t give you a procedure room.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I just need something at least close to a sterile environment.

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: I need 10 more nurses.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Brenda, listen, listen. She’ll die.

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: At least she’ll have a bed, then. Put that over there.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: Are there dead people in those cabinets?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I hope that’s who’s in there. Just be calm, relax.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: Ow, ow.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hang on, hang on. Almost done.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So, you went to Hopkins for both undergrad and med school?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s in a band.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Totally. What kind of music do you play?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, dude. You are so hired.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not a chance.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tattoo.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nonconformity, right. I can’t remember the last time I saw a 20-something kid with a tattoo of an Asian letter on his wrist. You are one wicked free thinker. You want to be a rebel? Stop being cool. Wear a pocket protector like he does and get a haircut. Like the Asian kids who don’t leave the library for 20 hours stretches, they’re the ones who don’t care what you think. Sayonara.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So should I go through all the resumes looking for Asian names?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, the Asian kids are probably just responding to parental pressure, but my point is still valid.

utterance.speaker: Teammate 1
utterance.content: So when do they think you’re getting out of here?

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: I don’t know.

utterance.speaker: Teammate 2
utterance.content: You don’t look sick.

utterance.speaker: Teammate 1
utterance.content: Better hope you’re not, this equipment looks like it’s 100 years old.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Just got it out of storage. It is the previous generation, but it works just fine. Could you guys give us a second?

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: If it’s good news, you can tell them.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Okay. We’re pretty sure it’s not cancer.

utterance.speaker: Teammate 2
utterance.content: Hey, that’s great.

utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: I’ll call your parents.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, we still can’t release her. We still don’t know yet exactly what’s causing the – Mary?

utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: What’s wrong?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s having an absence seizure. Mary, you okay?

utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: She looks fine.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I need some help over here! Push two milligrams Ativan, stat!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are you sure it was an absence seizure?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Absolutely. She was totally unresponsive and unaware of what was going on around her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do you mind? We’re trying to work.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We should get back out there. Cuddy’s going to be looking for us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Looking, but not finding. You do an EEG?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Seizure frequency’s increasing. They’re almost constant now. 5 in the last half hour.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which tells us…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s definitely in the brain.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And it’s getting worse.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And? Good lord, are you having a bowel movement or a baby?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Could be barbiturate withdrawal.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, can’t be drugs. She’s tested at every meet she competes in.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: A bleed in the brain can cause seizures.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Rat poison. Could also cause the neck pain.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You think she’s eating off the floor of her folks’ garage?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Doesn’t have to be.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Who would poison a 12-year-old?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, let’s see now, there’s the 18-year-old has-been that she beat out to make Nationals, the has-been’s parents, jealous siblings, sociopathic swim fan, and then there’s just your plain old garden variety whack job. Hey! You know what a hemorrhoid is?

utterance.speaker: Kid
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, google it. And try some Raisin Bran instead of the donuts. Okay, do a CT scan, check for intercranial bleeding.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not a chance, radiology’s totally swamped.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If our patient’s bleeding into her brain, she’s gonna be dead in 8 hours.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She could be, but a meningitis patient will be without a CT scan.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: When I was in med school, I had this old professor –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: -- who touched you in the naughty place?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Before the CT scan was introduced, he specialized in transcranial ultrasound.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmm. Ancient, but if there’s enough bleeding it might work. Okay, do what the guy who didn’t specialize in neurology said.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It was my idea!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’ve still got to cover Q-Z.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry I’m late, I was taking a dump.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Dr. Petra Gilmar, Dr. Gregory House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You actually speak four languages, or you just banking on never being interviewed by anyone who does?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why are you leaving Dr. Hazel? Did you fall for him and can’t handle it, or is it the other way around?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yes, well, pretty much every fellowship ends that way.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You Jewish?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is it true what they say about Jewish foreplay?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Uh, uh…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I heard four.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, that’s great. I think that’s all we’ll need. Thank you for coming by.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That’s our Hitler!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No way.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Are you kidding? Her background’s perfect, she’s smart, she can obviously deal with your insanity…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did you see her shoes?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Her shoes? What, did your horoscope in Vogue tell you to avoid women wearing green shoes?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The eyes can mislead, the smile can lie, but the shoes always tell the truth.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: They were Prada. It means she has good taste.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They were not Prada. You wouldn’t know Prada if one stepped on your scrotum.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Okay, well, they were nice, pointy…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exactly, they were stylish, and very painful to wear. Only an incredibly shallow and insecure woman would rather be in pain all day then wear a decent looking, comfortable shoe, and that’s exactly the type I don’t need around here.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, someone who can handle a lot of pain is exactly the type you do need.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Excuse me.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m ultrasounding your head. You’re still having seizures. This should help us figure out what’s going on.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Blue form to the security guard.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re not going to be happy with anyone.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what, your advice is... hire someone I’m not happy with and be happy?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, my advice is much more subtle. Stop being an ass. You always find some tiny little flaw to push people away.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Now it’s people. I thought we were talking about fellowship applicants.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You have a history of this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, when I do decide to push you away, I hope there’s a small person kneeling behind you so you fall down and hurt your head.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Take these, there’s water over there, blue form to the guard, and you’re done. You had the perfect person, and you blew it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You saw the shoes!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m not talking about her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re talking about Cameron.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m talking about every woman you’ve ever given a damn about.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cameron is so not perfect.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, nobody’s perfect.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mother Teresa?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Dead.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Angelina Jolie?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No medical degree.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Now who’s being picky?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re going to wind up alone, House.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You were right, there’s a significant bleed in her temporal lobe.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No poisons. Did a tox screen on her blood, urine and hair, nothing. Did ‘em twice.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He’s a little dehydrated, put him on a saline drip and give him some orange juice.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need an operating room and a surgeon.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh, well, given the current crisis I’m tempted to say no, but since you’ve been so sweet to me today –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Our little mermaid is bleeding into her temporal lobe.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How fast can you have her prepped?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 20 minutes.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’ll have a surgeon in the room in 10.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Mr. and Mrs. Carroll?

utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: This is Dr. Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The operation went well. The intercranial pressure’s been relieved and the swelling’s already going down.

utterance.speaker: Coach
utterance.content: No, nothing like that.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’re sorry, we still don’t know.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No toxins, no tumor, no bone cancer.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Adrenal failure could cause the rash, fever and muscle pain. Maybe it’s some sort of genetic kidney disorder.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No family history, and no blood in her urine or…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not yet.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You want to do a differential based on symptoms that might happen?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Got a better idea?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Stop it. Stop looking for things we don’t know and focus on what we do know. What do we actually know besides what’s up there? Come on, how hard can it be to tell me what you already know?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’s 12.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She spends a lot of time at the pool, so exposure to chemicals.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She travels a lot.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But never out of the country.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What else? Come on!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We’re missing something.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, if I knew that it wouldn’t be missing.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Maybe she’s adopted and we’ve got the wrong history.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, she’s got her mom’s eyes and a red patch of hair just like dad.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What about an allergic reaction?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Could explain the rash and muscle pain, but not the bleeding or seizures.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s a lot of balloons.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Think she’s allergic to polyester?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not unless she’s been competing in the nude all these years.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Then what are you thinking? What do the balloons mean?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What if the rash isn’t a rash?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What are you talking about?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who gave her the balloons?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Some of the girls from her team. They’ve been visiting her pretty regularly, but none of them are sick.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What about the guys?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: None of them are sick either.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which guys visited her?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Actually, none.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s cute, she’s nice, she’s a kick-ass diver. You’d think the guys would be falling over themselves to get close to her.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s 12. The youngest guy on her team is 16.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, so maybe they’re just not interested. Or…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: They’re avoiding her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There any cell fragments in her blood smears?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, red blood cells were intact.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Check ‘em again.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Blood looks like it’s been put through the blender, now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You done yet?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You were right. Rash wasn’t a rash, she’s bleeding into her skin. It’s purpura.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Thrombocytopenia purpura?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Starts with T. You were so close.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What could have set it off? She had no trace of E. Coli in her cultures, she’s obviously not menopausal, so no estrogen.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There is one other possible cause.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Oh, God.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pregnancy cause all kinds of chemical and biological changes in a woman’s body. Or a girl’s body, as the case may be. In extremely rare cases, everything goes haywire. It’s called TTP. Blood starts clotting like crazy, clogs the vessels in your brain and kidneys. Red blood cells end up getting shredded as they squeeze past the clot like a fat guy in a crowed bar. I’m sure you know what that’s like. You’re only 12, but you’re all grown up, right? Travel on your own, hang out in hotel rooms getting room service with your teammates, maybe someone sneaks in a couple of beers, you start playing spin the bottle… next thing you know you’re waking up in nothing but your socks.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: It wasn’t like that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course not. You wanted it.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: Yeah, I did. He turned out to be a jerk, but…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, under New Jersey law the term is ‘felon.’

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: I knew what I was doing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We’re going to have to do something called plasmapheresis. It cleans the antibodies from your blood. We’re also going to have to terminate the pregnancy.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: You’re going to tell my parents?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Someone should. Rock paper scissors?

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: They don’t need to know. I’ll be all right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course you will. If you’re old enough to bleed out of your vagina, obviously you’re old enough to handle a simple thing like an abortion without Mommy and Daddy’s help.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: You’re going to tell my parents?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Under New Jersey law, you’re the boss.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your daughter has TTP. Don’t worry, it’s curable, she’ll be fine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Some really big words that you’ve never heard before and when we’re done we’ll never hear again. Have a nice day.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh, in a few days. She needs some minor surgery to remove the underlying cause before we can do the… another really big word.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She has an abnormal growth in her abdomen.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s very simple. We do it here all the time.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, no. I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You’re doing good.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Feeling okay?

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You should be, your platelet count’s up.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How’s your neck? Looks good. Anything else we can get you?

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: No thanks.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Mary
utterance.content: Yeah. Can I see my mom and dad?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Plasmapheresis is working, she’s going to be fine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There is no opening.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House, you have to hire someone.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know. The position’s been filled.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exactly.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You figure if you keep arguing I’m going to cave, admit it’s all a lie, and hire you?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Do you need your parking validated?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t want to interview anyone else.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re interviewing? I thought you’d just have them send a headshot along with their CV.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hah. That’s good. And why I need you around. To keep me in my place.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I can’t come back, I told you that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wasn’t listening.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You want me to listen to you more? I can do that.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Right. I already accepted a position somewhere else.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: With who?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yule, at Jefferson.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unaccept it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because Yule is boring. He’s pedantic and preachy. Because he’s short. Because I want you to come back.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Not good enough.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Want more money? A car allowance, better parking space?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Dinner. And not just a meal between two colleagues. A date.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’ll come back to work if I go out on a date with you?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, it’s a deal.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: See you tomorrow morning.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t be late.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I won’t.
